nor Phin M'Cool himſelf, to comb my head wid a ſtick!

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: (Aſide.) He! he! he! Surely you won't refuſe the honor, Mr. Truſhoop?

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Fath! an there's no honor thereabouts, honey!

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Hah! hah! hah! ſurpriſing • y humorous.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: (Aſide.) He is ſo exceſſively witty and comical, tis almoſt impoſſible to do any buſineſs where he is.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen,—have you ſeriouſly conſidered what you're going about?—Our warfare is not with the men of this world, we have to engage with principalities and powers of darkneſs, with inv • ſibles, dem • n • , and hobgoblins; far more powerful than the united legions of the moſt invincible monarchs on earth: therefore, the utmoſt exertion of your courage and every nerve, will be abſolutely and indiſpenſibly neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: The thoughts of thoſe infernals ſhocks me ſo, I can ſcarcely help trembling!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I tink I hab courage enough!—

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p:
Not the leaſt ſhadow of a doubt, brother Rac
• oon, you have ever been ſuper-eminently diſtinguiſhed for your ſuperior courage and military ſkill!

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: Aye, aye, you're a happy man! your courage is conſtitutional!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: So it is—ſo it is—but for me—Oh dear! oh dear!

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: Hoot, mon! awa, awa! we a yere yealping, na mare o yere whigmeleeries! (Sings.)

lg.l: 'Tis money maks the coward brave,
An freedom gies to ev'ry ſlave,
My gude brod-ſword, Ize ſoon diſpla',
An drive thoſe warlocks far awa. A • drive, &c.
Stan' ye a ſtill an ſee how tight,
A Scotchman we • he deel wull fight,
Ize toozle him e'en at my eaſe;
Drive imps and warlocks down the braes.
Drive imp • , &c.
My life Ize lay to a Scotch bawbee,
Ize grup him fauſt ye ſoon ſal ſee,
Rare ſport, my lads, troth! ſoon Ize ſhow,
What a bonny highland lad can do!
What a bonny, &c.
Be he the deel, or what he wu • l,
By Andra's-ſaint! he'll ha his full,
Quick 'boot his heed, my ſword ſhall pla',
Mak 'im quut his legs, an' gang awa
Mak 'im quut, &c.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Excellent indeed! that ſong has inſpired me with a little courage.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear it! I hope it will inſpire us all, and have the ſame effect as the Marſellois'-hymn!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Well, are you all furniſhed with tools?

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I provide de pick-axe, de ſpade, and de ſpit,— I left dem wid a friend, but I can ſoon get dem.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Now, gentlemen, let's fix on a watch-word, whereby we may know each other in the dark.

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: Right, Sir! the papers inform us, the treaſure was carried up the creek, on board a canoe.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: A very good watch-word! Mr. Parchment.

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: Then let it be canoe! as it has a reference to the concealment of the treaſure.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Be it ſo—I like the word well.
Troth! Ize na objection, ſae we con underſtond ane anither.

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: I like the word, it has a ſoft ſound, and readily conveyed.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: The devil a hare myſalf ca • how it is, or what it is, canoe! or bote! 〈…〉 the money!

lg.l: By Shaint Patrick, deer honey's, no longer let's ſtay,
But take lave altogather an bundle away,
To the plaſhe under ground, where the trazure's expos'd;
An bring that to light, which ſhall ne'er be diſclos'd.
An now we have got it, my jewels, ohone!
For kaaping it ſnug—arra! let me alone!
We'll ſing Phillalew! at the ſight of the pelf,
An, as to the ſharing—lave that to myſelf.
Arra! fale how I'll wurk, wid my peck ax an ſpade,
For ſure I was nurs'd to the turf-cutting trade,
In bright Tipperara an ſmiling Tyrone;
An if you'll all help me, we'll all dig alone.
Come, come then away, to the plaſhe we'll retrate,
If the devil ſhou'd mate us, he'd ſurely get bate,
I'll faſſen my leg wid a pare of good brogues;
An I'll follow afore, all the way my ſweet rogues.
An now we have got it, we'll roar an we'll bawl,
An ſing, fath! like locuſts in winter an fall,
With ſhamrough in hat, deel a down will we lay;
But dance all night long, on St. Patrick's day,
The bagpipes ſhall fiddle Graamudgey gramagh,
While we ſwill down Skolrankey an good uſquebagh,
When I wawk in the ſtrate, I'll be led by a trupe;
Coming after an crying,—"Long life to Truſhoop!"

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: An excellent ſong 'pon my ſoul! well compos'd and well ſung!

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: And well tim'd too! he! he! he!—Is it one of your own compoſition, Mr. Truſhoop?

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Why you devil you!—do you tink now, an I'd ſing any body's ſongs but my own!—by my ſowl! now, an I'll chalenge the whole college of Dublin it's ſelf, to fellow me the like of it!

sp.speaker: Hum, Quad. and Parch.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Hah! ha! ha!—a queer dog! an eccentric genius!—Well, gentlemen▪ at eleven o'clock we're to meet at the ſtone-bridge, near the mill;—it will not be prudent to go altogether, leſt we be diſcover'd; whoever arrives there firſt, let him wait for the reſt, and as they approach they muſt hail with the watch-word, canoe!—thoſe within muſt anſwer with the ſame word; by obſerving this, we ſhall prevent miſtakes and diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Aye!—aye! the utmoſt care and circumſpection are neceſſary, we can't be too cautious; the object we are purſuing is equal to one whole year's revenue of the United States!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Fath! and I'll hollow canew! an canew! all night long in the morning, if you plaze.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Unleſs you're determined to follow implicitly my directions, when we come to action, 'twill be in vain to proceed.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: I'll do nothing but what you order, Mr. Rattletrap, indeed I won't! the ſpirits won't hurt us, I hope?

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Don't be afraid—take no raſh ſteps—follow my directions, and not a hair of your heads ſhall be injured! Now, gentlemen, 'tis time to cloſe, 'tis needleſs to ſay any more, now the plan's ſettled. Remember eleven o'clock, at the ſtone-bridge, each of you repair home, and bring all your tools with you, we'll break up for the preſent, I'll away home, and put on my magic habit—otherwiſe, I ſhall have no power over the inviſibles!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I'll go and get de tools, and bring a little refreſhment wid me.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Fath! an I'll fatch my gauging-rod, an all the tools in the ſhop, if you want um, becaze why—I'll have no 'caſion to uze um after this, honey!

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: Ize feetch my Andra we me, an then Ize fece the deel himſ ••• ! 〈◊〉 he appear.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: And I'll bring • he inſtruments with me, they are all in excellent order, and well prepared.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Now gentlemen, l • t's go with good hearts, there's nothing like putting a good face on theſe matters. If you'll bear chorus, I'll ſing you a ſong before we ſet off. Come, fill your glaſſes.

sp.speaker: All, ſay,
sp.p: With all my hear • ! They fill their glaſſes▪

lg.l: The merchant roams from climes to climes,
Rega • dleſs of his pleaſure,
To hardſhips and fatigue reſigns,
When in purſuit of treaſure.

Chorus—And a digging, & •
▪
See now the lucky hour it comes,
With pick-axe and with f • ade,
A little digging,—oh! my ſons,
And then our fortune's made! Chorus.
Let's boldly venture on the ground!
And ſeize the glorious cheſt,
No joy on earth like gold is found,
To eaſe the human breaſt! Chorus.

div.head: SCENE III. A Room in Truſhoop's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Dolly!—Dolly!—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Come hither, girl!—quick! quick!

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Coming, Ma'am.— (Aſide.) What the deuce i • the matter now?—ſure the houſe is on fire!

sp.speaker: Mr. Truſ.
sp.p: Why Doll Sword • I ſay—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Here, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: How • ong you ſtay, huſſey?—a body muſt ſplit their troats afore you cum—go your ways, an put on the tay-kittel, quick! make haſte girl! do you hare?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes ma'am— (Aſide.) —Is that all? Exit Dolly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: How ſhe ſtands?—Gaping—I ſeem in a flutter—my heart fales as light as a fedder,—I don't know what ales me—poor Truſhoop! an I wonder what he'll think, when I tell him all poor devi • ! an why didn't he tell me himſelf then? an I ſhou'dn't have ſcowlded him, an bate him, an ſtarved him ſo; but ſure, an its his own fault, but I'll ſoon make it up with him, Dolly! I ſay.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Does the kittle bile?—you're a plagey while about it.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Juſt now, ma'am. (Aſide.) Plague on yourſe'f! you're in a devil of a hurry, I think!—won't give one time to blow the fire, and juſt come from ſtuffing herſelf at Mrs. Trowell's, and not ſatisfied; I'll warrant her, ſhe's drank twenty diſhes of tea, and eat half a cord of toaſt and butter!—I hate ſuch gormandizing devils!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: It ſeems ev'ry minnet was an hour with me, I fale vary comical—well, it will be over bye an bye, an fath! an I'll have a better carpet than Mrs. Trowell's, an all theſe ould faſhion chairs, an tables, an luckin-glaſſes.—I'll pack to the vandue, an I'll buy good Moll-Hoggeny ones—plate, china, an ev'ry thing alſe, ſhall be of the neweſt taſte an higheſt cut, an why ſhou'dn't it? ſure an I can afford it now? Augh! an good luck to 'um, I ſay.—Dolly, now an what are you about?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Blowing the ſire, ma'am. (Aſide.) What the devil do you think?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Why now! an how long will you blow it?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: 'Till it boils, ma'am.— (Aſide.) To be ſure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Why don't you cum then you pokeing toad you!

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Coming Ma'am. (aſide.) I believe in my ſoul! ſhe's got the influenza, or the ravenous fever, or ſomething!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Well, an that ſelf ſame Mrs. Trowell, is a Jewel of a woman,—what paſhence ſhe has; an I wiſh I had half ſo much; but fath! an I never will— An why don't you come, you ſtomakin, with the tay-kittel? bring it along, I ſay!

sp.speaker: Dolly,
sp.p: Yes, ma'am! I'm coming. (Aſide) Curſe the kettle, it will never boil, I can't make it boil for my ſoul! ſmoaking my eyes out, and be bother'd ſo, I ſwear! I'll plague myſelf no longer about it, ſhe ſhall have it as it is, boil or not boil, the devil a bit I care!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Well cum away then, you pokeing toad you!

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: (aſide.) O! hold your jaw! you brimſtone devil!—Coming ma'am!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: An did it bile now?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, over and over again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Curſe you, an what made you ſo long then?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: To make it boil well, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
Dolly.
sp.p:
Yes, ma'am. (Aſide.) Hitey titey, and what's all this going on? ſome fun, I believe in my ſoul! Hah! hah! hah!—Oh! goodee, goodee oh! we ſhall ſee preſently.
Exit DOLLY.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ
sp.p: Well indeed! an I believe it's true enuff, an I have dram't it, or read it in ſome ould alminac ſomewhere, that "there is great joy over one ſinner that rapanteth." Troth! an I'm ſhure an I rapant of of ſtarving him ſo, an poor Truſhoop will have grate joy now, when he knows what I'm going about to do for him, poor ſowl! an he muſt be vary hungry, ſo he muſt, not a drop has he ate in my houſhe, this ſix days to cum, an indeed, an indeed, he is one of the beſt huſbands I ever ſee! Exit.

div.head: SCENE IV. A Room in Moll Placket's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: What cheer, Moll? let's taſte your head, (Kiſſes her.) How ſtands the wind? is the coaſt clear? no danger of the enemy?

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: No, no, he has no certain time of coming, except after church on Sundays; and then he never fails, if the old fellow ſucceeds in this night's enterpriſe, I'll make your fortune for you, my boy!

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Why! what the devil has Raccoon ſpied now? is there a galloon in chaſe? or, is he going to turn pirate?

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: No, no, but he may thank the pirates for it!

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: How, how Moll? tell me, you little dear dog you, (Chucking her under the chin.)

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: I tell you indeed!—a body wou'd—well, can you keep a ſecret then?

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Aye! can I, as ſnug as a Free-maſon; If ever I blow you, blaſt me! you know me better: If one word goes through my head rails, the devil blow me to Halifax, or Botany-Bay.—Aye Moll! the next hurricane blow me off the main-top-gallant-yard! three leagues aſtern, and be ſwallow'd up like Jonathan ſwallow'd the whale! That's enough! and now I'll kiſs the book on it. (Kiſſes her.)

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Well, come, I'll te • l you—You muſt know, that Mr. Hum has got a letter, and a heap of papers, from his ſiſter-in-law in England, giving an acco • n • , where there's a vaſt deal of money, that was formerly buried by the pirates!

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Money! buried by the pirates? the • evil!— aye Moll, that's true! I've often heard that Blackbeard hid his money, ſomewhere by the river's ſide; but how the devil came ſhe by the papers?

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Why you fool!—ſhe's Captain Blackbeard's great-grand-daughter, and they were preſerved in the family till they were ſent to Mr. Hum, and you know Raccoon is a Free-maſon too, ſo he is to aſſiſt him, and they are to go ſhares.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: But how do you know that Hum's a Free-maſon?

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Why he told me ſo, and they always call one another brother, and they keep this buſineſs as ſecret as their maſonry, but I wheedled Raccoon out of it, in ſpite of all his cunning.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: By heav'ns! I ſhou'dn't like him on board the Europa!—he'd make a damn'd fiſt in the Killecranky trade—he'd throw out a ſignal, and the cuſtom-houſe officers wou'd ſoon bear down on us—away goes ſhip and cargo by the maſt—by the Lord Harry, he'd ſoon make beggars of my owners—But tell us, Moll, how the devil did you pump it out of him?

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: That's none of your buſineſs, ſauce-box— women like me, have always a lure to catch the men's ſecrets!

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: True Moll—but we'll talk further on this ſubject another time, this ſort of chit-chat keeps us at long ſhot, let's ſtep into the ſtate-room, you know the old ſaying, "Time and tide waits for no one."

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p:
Softly!—don't be too haſty, let's make the door faſt firſt. (She locks the door.) Though I love your
little finger better than Raccoon's whole body; yet I muſt keep in with him.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Aye! that's true Moll—I ſhould be loth to quarrel with an owner, becauſe he did not underſtand navigation!

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: You know he maintains me, (after ſome ſort) finds me a houſe to live in, fathers all my children, and a huſband can do no more.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Right, Moll! now we're all ſnug, the hatches all ſecur'd. Sings.

lg.l: No girl with Placket can compare,
She is ſo charming, ſweet, and fair!
Such roſy cheeks, and nut-brown hair!
There's none like Molly Placket.
When'ere from ſea I do return,
I for my Placket ſinge and burn,
Good luck, Raccoon, 'tis now my turn,
Come, come my lovely Placket.

sp.p: Come Moll, now I'll try what the clues of your hammock are made of.

div.stage: (As they walk towards the upper part of the ſtage, a ſcene opens, and diſcovers a bed, table, and two bottles on it, with a broken glaſs over one, and a candle ſtuck in the other.—A knocking at the door.)

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Zounds! what's this? the devil has ow'd me a ſpite this long time, and now he has brought the enemy upon me, now I'm land lock'd!

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Who's there?—who's there?

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: (Without.) It's only me, my liddle dear pet— open de door.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Oh! curſe his head!—Pet's a coming! Pet's a coming, dear Cooney!

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Where the devil ſhall I ſtow myſelf? by the Lord Harry!—there's no dropping aſtern here.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Creep under the bed, and your as ſafe as a thief in a ſynagogue!

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Aye, Moll! down the fore-ſ • uttle, or, any port in a ſtorm, damme!

div.stage: Topinlift goes under the bed, and ſhe opens the door.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: What brings my dear Cooney back ſo ſoon? no misfortune, I hope.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: No, no; no misfortune, only I left ſum tings under de bed.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Curſe your contrivance, now I'm blown. What things, my dear Cooney, did you leave there? (Aſide.) Oh! invention! thou darling genius of my ſex, aſſiſt me, or I'm ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Nutting, my dear pet, but de ſpade, de pick-axe, and de ſpit. But, what makes you look ſo ſuppris'd! child?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: Why, I was afraid you'd catch me, and indeed you had like to have done ſo, (affects a laugh.) He! he! he!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p:
Seech what? ſeech how? What de debil do you mean by ſeech? Dad! I begin to tink it iſn't all lies dat I hear about you, Mrs. Placket, tell me this inſtant who you hab wid you, or I'll ſhake you like de debil! (He ſhakes her, and ſhe bawls.) What ••
• ebil, you tink to impoſe upon me, wid you he! he! he! I'll know de trute afore I done, huſſey!

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: Oh! my dear Cooney!—do let me go, and I'll tell you the truth—indeed I will.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: (Peeping.) Oh! the brimſtone whore!—I wiſh I was on board the Europa!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Well, come den—confine youſelf to de tru • e, huſſey!

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: (Peeping.) By the Lord Harry! the ſtorm gathers, we ſhall have foul weather ſoon—I muſt bowſe taught my rolling tackles!

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Lord Sir! I'm afraid to tell you—you look ſo angry—I'll tell you in the morning, when your paſſion's over.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I'll know it inſtantly, you vile ſtrumpet you— or I'll ſhake you to atoms. (Shakes her again, and ſhe bawls.)

sp.speaker: Top
sp.p: (Pe • ping.) It comes thicker and faſter,—here's a damn'd ſtink of bildge water along-ſide.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: I'll tell you all—if you'll let me go.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Tell den huſſey! dis minnet!
(Peeping.) Ava •• ! there—belay that, I muſt out tomkins, and prepare for a broadſide—damme.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Look at this book. (Gives him a Dutch almanac.)

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: (Peeping.) No nea • ! ſteady there!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: What of dat?—why it's High Dutch.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Can't you read it?

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: No—not I.

sp.speaker: Plack
sp.p: (Aſide.) I'm glad of it!—Why then, you muſt know▪ when I was about fifteen years of age, I lived at Germantown with my uncle, a high German Doctor, who could tell fortunes, find ſtolen goods, diſcover hidden treaſure, lay ſpirits, and raiſe the devil. And his whole art is contained in this little book.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: (Peeping.) By the Lord! ſhe ſteers well thro' the breaker • I was dam'd afraid ſhe had ſprung a leak, he pump'd her ſo helliſhly!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: You don't ſay ſo, pet?

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: But I do!—you ſhall hear—I'd juſt taken the book in my hand, and raiſed a familiar ſpirit, to enquire of him if you'd ſucceed in your undertaking, and he had juſt riſen thro' the floor, when you knock'd at the door.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: (Stares and trembles.) I declare you ſuppriſe me! let me get de tings, and I'll go.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: You muſt not yet, 'tis as much as your life is worth, to touch any thing before I have laid him.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: (Aſide.) By my ſoul! ſhe acts her part well; ſhe'd out-face truth, and out-brazen the devil! a girl after my own heart, damme.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Can you lay him den?—my dear pet.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Why yes!—I've rais'd and laid five hundred in my time.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: (Aſide.) That's true enough, my girl! but I'll ſecure the ſpit for fear of the worſt.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Oh! my dear pet, do lay him den.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Have you courage enough to ſee him, dear Cooney?

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: No, no, no, no!—dear pet.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: But there no avoiding it now, you'll ſee him only in part.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh! (Trembling) I biſh he was gone!

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: (Places Raccoon's back towards the bed.) Stand you here; don't ſtir an inch, bend your head a little that way, you may ſhut your eyes—he's viſible, but don't be afraid, he ſhan't hurt you. (She beckons to Topinlift, he comes from under the bed, ſhe meets him and puts an old blue petticoat over his head and ſhoulders, and reads.) Dunder unt vetter ſchleemer hoont, ein blixum kindt, ri • um tenealis amiſſee. (Topinlift overſets Raccoon, drops the ſpit, and runs off.)

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: (Looking frighten'd.) Mercy on me, here am I? Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Get up, dear Cooney!—did you ſee him?— you an't hurt I hope, my dear?—let me help you up. (She raiſes him) don't be frighten'd, he'll trouble you no more, he's a thouſand leagues off by this time. (She applies a ſm • lling bottle to his noſe, he ſtarts.)

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Oh! my dear pet! I—I—I nebber was ſo frighten'd in all my life! is he gone?

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Aye, far enough—didn't you ſee him go?

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I hab de glimp of him as he goed by, I tought he did carry away de corner of de houſe wid him. Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: (Runs to the bottle, and brings him a dram.) Drink this, dear Cooney, and you'll ſoon recover your ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: (Trembling, drinks.) Oh! I was'nt not afraid, a—a—only—

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Courage man!—you'll ſee ten times more before morning!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I tink he look like de ſailor.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Yes!—why he's the apparition of one of Blackbeard's crew, and as a confirmation that you'll obtain the treaſure, he threw, that ſpit on the floor as he went off.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: (Takes up the ſpit.) Why dis is de berry ſpit dat I put under de bed!

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: So much the better, it was a ſignal to be gone.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Well, I get de pick-ax and de ſpade, and den I'll go, but I muſt have dis liddle book to ſhow Mr. Rattletrap.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: No, no—it's high Dutch, he can't read it. (Takes it from him.)

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: (Goes to the bed and takes the pick-axe and ſpade.) Now one buſs, my dear pet, and den—

div.head: SONG XIV.
div.l: Oh! when I get de welt,
Dat's buried by de mill,
Enjoy long life an helt,
An pleaſure at my will.
What ſtore of gold I' • l bring,
My lovely pet to dee,
Den none but my poor ting
Shall ſhare de ſame wid me. Exit Raccoon.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p:
Well,—it's an old ſaying, and I think a true one:—When poverty comes 〈◊〉 the door, love flies out at the window. Really I have experienced the truth of it lately, and hadn't it been for Topinlift, and a few tranſient friends, I ſhou'd have been in a poor ſituation; for I'm ſure Raccoon's nothing belonging to him that can pleaſe me but his money, and I ſee very little of that. He p • omiſes mountains of gold! • ut I fancy he'll be deceived as well as myſelf! I'll truſt no longer to bare promiſes, when a woman finds herſelf deceived, and deprived of moſt of the comforts of life, ſhe has it always in her power, and ſhe muſt be a fool, if ſhe don't take her revenge in a way the moſt pleaſing to herſelf. Sings.
SONG XV.
Sure gold is the fuel that kindles the fire,
And ſerves for to fan up a woman's deſire,
To a fumbling fool that's decrepid and old:
For in all ſcenes of life, from the great to the little,
The bench, bar and pulpit, it ſuits to a tittle;
You're ſurely condemn'd, if you hav'n't the gold.
But if you have money▪ ne'er mind what your cauſe is,
But tickle their palms and you'll gain their applauſes;
No ſtateſman ſo great, ſo cunning, and bold,
But will truckle to you, for the ſake of your gold;
And ſhou'd you lack that—you are certainly ſold.
But hang this diſappointmen • !

lg.l: Let women of bus'neſs take care of their men,
If one won't ſuffice them—why, let them have ten.

div.head: SCENE V. A Room at Mrs. Truſhoop's.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Here he cums!—poor ſowl!—how magre he looks! I vow to St. Patrick! an I pity him!

div.stage: (MRS. TRUSHOOP meeting him with a bowl of punch.)

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: And was you after wanting me, my deer?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: To be ſure an I was, honey, an hares to you my jewel, and ſuſſex to your undertakins, dare! (Drinks.)

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: I thank you kindly, my deer!—but I don't know what you mane!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Never mind! drink hearty! (Drinks.) Take anudder pull at it, dare! (Drinks again.) Shure! an it's vary good punch.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: By my ſowl!—and it is ſo, it drinks for all the world like nectar-ambroſial! ſo it does.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Cum give me one of your ſwate ould faſhion kiſſes, dare! (Kiſſes him.) troth, an it ſeems like ould times now, juſt for all the wurld—let me take off your apern, honey, for ſhure an you'll have no more 'caſion for it after this. (She takes off his apron and throws it from her.)

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Why now, deer!—an what do you mane?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Never mind, ſit down, honey! ſure an you muſt be vary hungry?

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Indeed, and I am ſo!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Poor ſowl!—Dolly cum hither child.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Here! ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Here, my good child, take the kays an the big market baſket, an go your ways an open the pantry, an fetch up them two cowl roaſt ducks.—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ
sp.p: An the capers—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: An the anchobies, an the gammon—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am! (Going.)
(Aſide, looking ſurpris'd.) By my ſowl! this looks well on our ſide!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Come hither girl! an your going without half your arrant; an the packeld ſammon, an the horſe-raddiſh, an the cowl roaſt-beef—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am. (Going.)

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Augh hoogh! better and better.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Stop girl! I ſay—don't be in ſuch a hurry, an the kagg of lobſters, the packeld iceters, an the ſwate-oyl, you know your maaſter loves oyl, an it's vary haling to the belly.—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: (Smiling aſide.) Yes, ma'am—any thing elſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Why yes, huſſey! the jarr of olives— the Chaſter chaze—the nates-tung, the ſous'd rock, the potted pigeons, the apple-pie, the cowl potatoes, the whaſkey-jugg, an a hunder'd things more, but do tha • firſt.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: (Smiling aſide.) Why ma'am! this big baſket won't hold the half of them!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Why then, go an fatch the t'other big baſket, you fool you! have you no contraption?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: (Going and laughing aſide.) Hah! hah! hah! Well, I wonder what all this means? for this week paſt ſhe's been ſtarving him, and now ſhe's going to cram him like a ſtuff'd turkey! I believe in my conſcience, ſhe's light-headed! Exit Dolly.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Blaſſings on you, deer! but you're too good. Why now, when you are good, why then you are too good!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p:
No indeed! an indeed! an I an't, I can't be good enuff—fath! an you deſarve it all an more too.—Shall I ſend for ſome ſaſſages an aggs? an will
you have a nice ſpare-rib broyl'd, with ſome apple ſauce, honey?

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: No fath, deer! I think in my conſhence and heres enuff! why now, if I was an allephant, I cou'dn't ate the half of it? ſo I cou'd!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſh.
sp.p: Shure, but you muſt be vary hungry?

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Fath! an I am ſo and more too, but I muſn't make a beaſt of myſelf for all that! you know, deer!

div.stage: (Enter DOLLY, with the two big market baſkets heaped up.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: An have you forgot ev'ry thing, girl?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Why then fatch them in the parler, an lay the damaſk table cloth on the big table girl, an ſet i • off han'ſome an nate, your maaſter ſhall ſup in the parler, ſo he ſhall; an when your done all that, why, go your ways preſently, (not juſt now) an warm my bed vary well, an ſprad the curtins, do you hare, I ſay?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am. Exit Dolly.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Indeed, my deer! and I'm vary ſorry, you give yourſelf a grate dale of trubble for me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: No, ind • ed honey, an I do not!—an you know I was always plaz'd to ſee you ate harty.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Yes, my deer—but I forgot it lately!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Well! never mind it dare, I wiſh you good luck in your undertakins.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: I thank you my deer,—but what wou'd you be after now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Augh, fath!—the trazure, to be ſhure!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: What trazure?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Cum—cum, don't think to kape it a ſacre • from me—ſhure an I know all about it now!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: About what pray?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Hav'n't I towld you now?

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: (Aſide.) By my ſowl! and we're all ruin'd▪ ſome traytor has blow'd us! Some nonſenſe in your head.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Fath! an it isn't nonſenſe though—ſhure an Mrs. Trowell towld me all about it—as how you are going to dig for trazure, an a graite dale more—

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: And how does Mrs. Trowell know?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Fath! an vary well, ſhure an Trowell towld her all about it.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Augh! the book-ſworn? oath-breaking dog! oh! the traito • ! oh! the Judas! Augh! and Trowell and you muſt do gra • t p • n • ance for all this. Well, thank God! and I'm not book-ſworn!

sp.speaker: Mrs Truſ.
sp.p: No, my dare, no more you arn't; cum, never mind honey, let's go into ſupper.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: I'll follow, deer. (Aſide.) Augh! the ſ • ubber-degullion dog! Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE VI. A Room.
div.stage: (Enter DOLLY, with a warming p • n, and TERRANCE meeting her.)

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Oh! Terrance—I'm glad you're come! he! he! he!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe ſo! you want me to fatch a bucket of vater, an then kiſs you? don't you? ſay? (Chucking her under the chin.—Kiſſes her.)

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: No faith! I don't—but here's the devil to pay! he! he! you never ſaw the like in all your born days!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: What?—what the devil is it?—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Why you muſt go and fetch the prieſt! he! he! maſter and miſtreſs has made it up, and they're going to be married over again!
Hoot! the girl tawks like a fool!

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: No faith! I don't, the wedding ſupper's on the table, and ſhe's going to make him eat our two great big market baſkets full, all up at once, and faith! I don't know but the baſkets in the bargain he! he!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: By my ſowl! Dolly but I believe your'e crazy! —or

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: No, I an't!—you fool!—but you can't think, how kind ſhe has been to him, kiſſing and ſlobbering his chops about, like all the world—and the Lord? knows what, and treating him with punch—but I watch'd her, and ſhe took care to have the largeſt ſhare to herſelf.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Fath!—but I believe an you had a large ſhare too, by your tawk.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: No—the devil a drop I got of it!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Then your'e humbugging me, arn't you now Dolly?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: No, I an't 'pon honor!—only peep thro' the key-hole, and ſee what an elegant variety there is, for the wedding ſupper!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Hoot you fool!

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Peep thro' here!—can't you?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: (Peeps.) Oh! Jaſus!—a grate faſte by my ſowl! —ſhure enuff!—why there's enuff for the howl Kongraſs!—an nobody to ate it! the divil burn me!—but I'll have ſum of it!—if they don't ate it all! but what the divil's all this for? ſay Dolly?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: The Lord above knows!—I ſwear! I don't, no more than a horſe!—if I did, I would tell you indeed, Terrance.—We ſhall know more about it tomorrow, I think.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: The forerunner of anudder dam'd quarrel!

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: The devil may care for me!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: An me too—but ſure Dolly, an you can tell us a little more, about the maning of it?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p:
No faith! I can't—only miſtreſs went over the way this evening, to drink tea with Mrs. Trowell, and preſently after, ſhe came running home, quite out of breath, and bawl'd out, like a mad cow, bawling for her calf!—Dolly!—Dolly! three or four times,
(I thought the houſe had been on fire!—or ſome develiſh thing, or, other) and ordered me to put on the tea-kettle, in all haſte—and Oh! how ſhe bothered me, ſhe wanted it to boil, before the fire was made,— Lord! how vex'd I was—I could have cut her throat! —"does it boil?—does it boil?—make haſte girl!— how long you ſtay?—what are you poking about?"— (mimicking her) and called me baggage, and trollop, and a hundred bad names, you never heard ſuch a Billingſgate!—I never was ſo curſedly vext, and blinded with ſmoke, in all my life,—and was obliged at laſt to bring in the tea-kettle as it was, and the devil a boil it boil'd, no more than when I firſt put it on the fire—ſo I don't care!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: An ſerve her rite too—the owl'd Jazzebel!

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: But the beauty of it was, Terrance,—ſhe made me take the two big market baſkets, and go down into the cellar, and fetch up every thing there, for maſter to eat and drink, (faith! I almoſt broke my back with them, they were ſo heavy)—and call him out of the ſhop?—Oh! you never ſee ſuch a fidgetting as ſhe made!—

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: I'll warrant the Brimſtone made noyſe enuff! fath! an ſhe's no ſlouch at that! let's have anudder peep at um—Augh hoogh! an how he tares away at the roaſt ducks?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: I don't at all wonder at it—he's almoſt ſtarv'd!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: By my ſowl!—but this is a queer ſort of a reveluſhin—there's ſomething brewing, Dolly! take my word for it, but what are you after wid the wharming-pan?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Why you fool!—what do you think, when people's married? why they're going to bed together after ſupper, and ſhe ordered me to warm it.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Worſe an worſe—by my ſowl!—but there'll be a grate earthquake to-night! I expact—but you ſlut you, why you hav'n't been up yet to warm it, an the pans quite cowl'd.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Faith! I don't care! then let 'em lye the cloſer, and warm it themſelves.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Hah! hah! hah!— (A noiſe in the parlour, like moving of chairs.)

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Oh! gracious—they're coming to bed!—Run Terrance! don't let 'em ſee you for all the world!— hide yourſelf in the cow-ſtable, and when they're gone to bed, we'll partake of the wedding feaſt.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: That's rite Dolly—I'm diviliſh hungry and dry too!

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: I wont forget you, fly you devil!—fly! they are here. Exit Terrance.

div.stage: (Enter MR. and MRS. TRUSHOOP, with a candle, meeting DOLLY.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: An have you now, warm'd the bed well girl?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes ma'am, very well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: And ſprad the Kurtins?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Then go your ways, an clare the table, an put out the fire, and lock the dure, an go your ways bed.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Where's Terrance?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Gone to bed ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: How long firſt?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Two hours ago ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: How cum that?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: He ſaid he was ſleepy ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Truſ.
sp.p: Vary well, go your ways.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes ma'am, (Aſide) blatherum, lolling out her tongue and Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I. The place of action, n • ar the Mill and Stone-bridge.
div.stage: (Scene opens and diſcovers RATTLETRAP dreſs'd in his magic habit, with a dark lanthorn and candle, QUADRANT, with a magnet, rod, and wand, &c. &c. &c. an old iron bound cheſt, and SPI • FIRE, with a copper figure, repreſenting the head and ſhoulders of BLACKBEARD.)

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Well done Spitfire! the hole I ſee is made.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: Yes—yes—I've not been idle, ſince you left me.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: (Aſide) He's the very plan of a fellow!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: (Aſide) Not his fellow to be found—He has performed wonders!—But we muſt loſe no time, (looks at his watch) 'tis near eleven o'clock. (They poke in the cheſt, ſtones, brickbatts, broken bottles, and two or three ruſty looking pieces of ſilver.)

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: Come! come! let's bury it at once. (All aſſiſt, and bury the cheſt.)

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: (To Spitfire) Now we've nothing more to do, at preſent, than to ſee you deſcend into your ſubterranity —ſtep down!—ſtep down! and mind when I give the ſignal, throw fire-balls, and when they come to a ſight of the cheſt, puſh up the figure, and act as I have before directed you—Now be ſure you act the devil, as if you were going to deceive the devil himſelf, and we'll reward you deviliſhly well.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: And the devil take me if I don't! (Spitfire goes down the hole, and takes the figure, lanthorn, and candle with him.)

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: Now every thing is ready to receive them, and if our devil plays his part well—I think, we ſhall have a deviliſh merry night of it. He! he! he!—egad here's ſome of 'em coming! (They halloo without, Canoe! Canoe! thoſe within anſwer, Canoe! Canoe!)

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Where are the mud-mongers?

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: They're juſt at hand, we heard them, as we came down the hill. (Different voices without hallooing Canoe! Canoe! Canoe! Canoe! &c. thoſe within anſwering Canoe! &c.)

div.stage: (Enter WASHBALL, TRUSHOOP, BUCKRAM, RACCOON and TROWELL, with pick-axes, ſpades, ſhovels, ſpit, and ANDRA FERRARA ſhouldered.)

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: I tore my ſhins unaccountably, coming thro' the briers!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Fath! and I tumbled up the hill, 'till I got my futt in the boggs, and if I hadn't held faſt by the vater, I'd be drown'd.

sp.speaker: Hum and Quad.
sp.p: Hah! Hah! he! he!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Don't mind, gentlemen, what is de tore ſkin, or de cold foot, compar'd wid de proſpect of deſe riches?

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: By me ſaul! mon—and I chearg'd meſel we twa bottles to Ieeghten me nawſe, and thats a bonny guede in a dark neeght, and for fear o meeting we ony ſkoondrels, Ize feetch'd me Andra we me, as gude ſtuff as e're wa made in a ſcoteland!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Well gentlemen, I ſee we're all here, don't let us waſte time, let's be ſerious; keep ſilence! by the calculation I made this morning, by the Satellites, the treaſure muſt be near this place, (He takes an obſervation, and works his magnetic hazel-rod) the magnet works this way —

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I tought ſo.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Lave off your botheration!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Pray be ſilent! it draws exceſſive ſtrong this way. I feel myſelf interrupted by in viſibles! I can ſcarcely keep the rod in my hands, there! now I have it! it draws this way!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Dis is de berry place, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: And can't you now be azey, and howl'd your tung? you fool! you know nothing about it.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Oh! dear! what interruptions?

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Not a word! not a word! pray be ſilent! I'm near the place, the rod points to this ſpot—I'm near the centre, I know the rod to be true, I've tried its virtue, 'twas cut on All-hallows eve, at 12 o'clock at night, with my back to the moon, and the mercury injected while the ſap was running.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: (Aſide) By the holy ſtone! but I believe, he was born in the moon!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p:
(Draws a large circle with his wand, and ſays) Diapaculum interrav • , tenebroſſitas ſtravaganza! (Goes round the circle, and ſticks twelve pieces of iron-wire in the Periphery; each piece having a bit of paper cut out in the form of a ſtar on its head—as he ſticks them down, he names the twelve ſigns of the Zodiac.) Aries, Taurus, Germini, Cancer, Leo, Virgo, Libra, Scorpio, Sagitarius, Capriconius, Aquarius, Piſces, make no noiſe elſe you'll diſturb Jupiter, who is the moſt wakeful planet, and is now in his firſt ſleep. (He puts on a large pair of ſpectacles) Let me ſee! its now 12 o'clock, Jupiter in a ſound ſleep, a good omen! (He calls WASHBALL, TRUSHOOP, BUCKRAM, RACOOON, and TROWELL.) Take off your coats and jackets, (they pull them off) now ſtand within the cir
• le, (he places HUM, QUADRANT, and PARCHMENT, without the circle, at different poſts, and ſays) now keep a good look out, Canoe's the word, ſo don't forget it.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: (Aſide) The devil a forget, myſelf will forget! fath! and I will ſooner forget my prayers!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Now run down the ſpit and try this place—Mr. Waſhball.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: (Thurſt • down the ſpit, and ſays) Oh dear! it's very ſoft and ſluſhey.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Never mind! the better digging,—try it again, I k •• w its the identical ſpot!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Softer and ſofter, I feel it! I feel it! it ſtrikes againſt ſomething!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Then fall too all hands, and dig, and when the watch-word is given, fall flat on the ground. (They dig, he views the ſtars) now the Dragons head and the Scorpion's tail are in conjunction. Caſtor's in the wane, Procyon is ſtationary, but Sagitarius ſeems obnubilated, and faſt approaching to a ſtate of obtenebration! hah! I don't like that! it rather looks inauſpicious and portentous of ill!—but Syrius's right foot—

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: (Without) Canoe! (They anſwer Cance! and fall down within the circle. A fiddle is heard at a diſtance, playing badly.)

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Inferno atum, gaſtro fagnum!—Riſe and go on! 'twas nothing but a blind drunken fidler, and ſome company returning from Batchelors-hall.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: By my ſowl! now, and I've made a ſwate packle of my ſelf, all over full of mud! Augh! and I had the ſpawlpene here an I'd give him two or three handfulls of bothers wid my ſhelaley, ſo I wou'd'nt.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Deel tak me mon! but I dinna leke this, 'tis a foul drumlie pleece, gin I a wa we him, I'ze claw the tyke a wee bit, and brok his damn'd feedle!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Ah me!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Not a word gentlemen! proceed, (they dig) but Syrius's right foot, over Orion's left ſhoulder, looks well, and the Swan's tail near the Hydra's heart, has a promiſing appearance. (One fire-ball, the diggers frighten'd, and attempt to run out of the circle.) Don't ſtir an inch! if you break the mounds, I've no power!—dig! dig! Conjabetima, morentium habavo, omnibuſque contubernalium! and this leap-year is not unfavorable. (Another fire-ball, with a roaring below, at which they are terrified.)

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Augh! how my hart bates!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Come near Mr. Rattletrap! Oh! dear! Oh! dear! I ſhall faint!

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: I'd give all my ſhare, I had never come! mercy on me!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Oh! Oh!—I wiſh I was at home, I nebber wou'd come again!

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Hoot! canna ye a be queeit?

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Never fear! I'll protect you!—Hobonos cum verigos, omne croxibus influvientum! dig! dig! (viewing the ſtars) but yet certain appearances, puts me to a ſtand, baffles my utmoſt ſkill, and indicates an infernal oppoſition! I'll try my Omphaloptic glaſs. Aye! now I diſcover the cauſe of the oppoſition! I now diſtinctly perceive, thro' a boundleſs radiant apperture, the tail of a huge Comet! like a monſtrous, overgrown ram-cat, with his hind legs, kicking and ſcratching the Planets and Stars about, as tho' they were marbles or ſnow-balls! ſtrange Phenomenon! a glorious opportunity this would be, for a young divine, to ſtudy Aſtro-Theology! one peep thro' this, would inſtantaneouſly and eternally ſilence, the whole hoſt of ſceptics!
sp.l: "Fierce meteors ſhoot their arbitrary light
And Comets march with lawleſs horrors bright!"

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: (Without) Canoe! (All anſwer Canoe! and fall down.)

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Metantaborabulum, exultiſſimo ocabulum mongrabo! Riſe! it was nothing but an old cow paſſing along! go on! (All riſe and dig.)

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Damn the Hawkie for a dorty beech! wha the deel does ſhe want here? does ſhe tak us for Bulls an be damn'd to her?

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Arra deer! and how my wife will ſcowld, when I fatch her the money, for ſpileing my new brogues.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p:
Sagitarius is now clear, and the Orb of the
Moon, is in contact with Jupiter, good! Sextile in conjunction with Quartile right! (He waves his wand) Saturn is a metallic planet, and tho' in common the moſt dull, is now perfectly pellucid, and out ſhines even Venus herſelf! this is the beſt ſign of all! (Another fireball, a roaring below.)

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Oh! dear! Oh dear!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! Oh!—what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: Defend us! defend us!—Mr. Rattletrap!— Oh!—

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Theſe inviſibles will diſturb you awhile, now your juſt upon it. Conjunction, oppoſitorium, placabulum fomoſo!—dig away! Arcturus now appears, Conſtellatione planetarium! Venus is now the morning ſtar, and is eclipſed four digits. (Two or three fire-balls, and a roaring below, the diggers terrified.) Now their rage increaſes! we'er near the treaſure, don't be afraid, I am with you, their fiery darts will ſoon be over, dig! dig! Cummeritantibus conſiderationibus, terrabandum ophagnum!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Oh!—Oh!—Oh!—

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Quut mon! quut! wha the deel cares for em, dig mon! dig!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Oh!—Oh!—what will become of us?

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p:
Stick to it!—Stick to it! (They dig.) Theſe nocturnal obſervations, ſometimes deceive the brighteſt aſtronomers! the whole planetary ſyſtem now changes and appears to have a centrifugal motion—now whirls within a huge vortex, with a velocity, beyond the power of mathematics to calculate, now orbicular! now circumvolves! and Georgium Sidus, forms an obtuſe angle, whoſe Hypothenuſe ſeems offuſcated, or eclipſed by the horns of the Moon, and whoſe perpendicular is geocentric with our earth! theſe appearances are new to me—beyond my Taliſmanic powers to comprehend! preternatural! utterly un ••• cogitable! In
ſhort, I have never experienced ſuch a rare Synchroniſm, ſince I have had any knowledge of the Occult ſciences! however I now perceive a ray of hope! Hiccius Doccius! now Caſſiopaea and the Bears-tail, are on the meridian! exceſſive lucky!

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: (Aſide) He performs to admiration!

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: (Aſide) Incomparably well, by Jupiter! He! he! he! (Two or three fire balls, and an increaſe of roaring below.)

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Mercy on me! I ſhall faint—Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Haud up mon!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: O my poor ting, I wiſh I had ſtay'd wid you!

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: I tremble every joint of me. O Lord! oh!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: (Aſide) Fath! and my knees tump togedder, like a pare of pot-hooks, but I won't tell um for all that.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Gentlemen!—ſummon up all your courage! —don't be puſillanimous! dig! dig!—the enemy's fire is nearly exhauſted!—Tincturum, corroſivum, ſublimatum! (Takes an obſervation.)

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: (Without, aſide.) Come let's drink while the fools are digging. He! he! he! (They drink, and point, and laugh at the diggers.) Poiſonous exhalations riſe from this deviliſh ſwamp! I'm afraid old Waſhball will get the Cholera-morbus. He! he! he!

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: (Without, aſide.) I'm rather of opinion he'll get the Perip-no-money. Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: (Without, aſide.) By the Lord Harry! that's well ſaid! I'm entirely of your opinion—no money. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p:
Every thing now looks well! fine appearances! Spica, ſouth eleven degrees fifty eight minutes, good! to-morrow is Sexageſima ſunday, good! Lyra, ſouth, ſets nine minutes after one this morning, good! the horns of the moon in Apogee, good! Bull's-eye riſes, good again! Venus riſes, very good! ſhe ſets S. Weſt obliquely towards the mines of Mexico and Peru, excellent!
In ſhort! the macrocoſm of the whole viſible ſyſtem of nature, are ſtrongly in our favor! a certain ſign of ſucceſs! occidental! occidental! glorious!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: (Aſide) By St. Patrick! but I ſwatt ſwately!— by my ſowl! now but its harder work than digging parat • es!

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: (Aſide) Only ſee how it drops off me! I wiſh it was all over.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: (Aſide) It's good for your helt, you devil you. Fath! and I would be very ſorry, but I had one good drink of whiſkey juſt now my deer.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Have a little patience! the bull's eye is this moment ſtationary and opacous! it would prove fatal to drink now! it would moſt aſſuredly bring on the Hydrophobia! dig! dig! before the eclipſe comes on! our ſucceſs altogether depends upon your induſtry, one ſecond of time now well employ'd, is worth a whole year! go on! go on! redouble your vigilance!

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: (Aſide, without) Let's give 'em another tumble in the mud.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: (Without, aſide) With all my heart,—he! he! —Canoe! (The diggers anſwer Canoe! and fall down.)

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Facinorum, muddum, daſhum, ſplaſhum. Riſe and go on! it was nothing but a diſtant barking of dogs. (Viewing the ſtars.)

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Oh dear! I can't ſupport it any longer! it will kill me! indeed it will! theſe curſed dog days are coming faſt upon us!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: By my ſowl and you're right—fath an they bark all night long in our alley!—O Jaſus! and what a packle I'm in?

sp.speaker: Hum, Parch. and Quad.
sp.p: (Without, aſide) Hah! hah! he! he! (alternately.)

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p:
Benedictum, atmoſphericum! hold out only ſix minutes, three quarters and the 197th part of a minute
and we have it! (Pointing to the ſtars with his wand) luckily for us! the ſtar Wormwood (as mentioned in the Revelations) is in a ſtate of occultation! Mars approaching omnolency! and Bacchus as drunk as a piper, ſucceſs is certain! (Fire-balls and a terrible roaring.)

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Oh! I'm dead! I'm dead!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: I'll ſoon vivificate you! here, take a little Aqua me Rabulus, it coſt me half a crown a ſpoonful. (He drinks it off.)

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Stop! ſtop! don't drink it all!

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: You needn't halloo to him, don't you know a man can't hear whil • he's drinking?

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Fath 'an I never know'd that before! by my ſowl next time I'll be up wid him, and I'll halloo, ſtop, ſtop you devil you, afore he begins.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: That's reeght mon!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: How it revives the animal ſpirits?

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: The devil burſt you, and that's all the harm I wiſh you!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: (Aſide) Ha! ha!— (Looks at his watch) the time's juſt expired—pray be ſerious! dig away! dig away! now for your lives! I feel the ground move under my feet!—the treaſure is ſtruggling, it wants to be relieved from it's long impriſonment, dig!—dig!— Theophraſticum, Privilegium! now the whole hoſt of devils are pulling againſt us, and levelling all the darts of infernal fury at us!

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: I feel the cheſt!—I feel the cheſt!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: I ſee it! I ſee it!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Ne plus ultra! up with it, up with it▪ all's our own! (The ghoſt appears and ſpits fire, the diggers with uplifted hands, looking at it.)

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: How he ſquints.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: The deel me care! troth mon an he looks leke auld Squintefego at Aberdeen!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p:
Fath an he ſquints ſure enuff, but no more
than a gentleman ought to ſquint, but I've a grate mind to wauk off wid myſelf, for the devil burn me▪ but I believe he'll burn us all up, by my ſoul! and he's no ſlouch of a fellow!

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Troth mon!—he cuts a ſhacking figure!

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: He's got a beard like a ram-goat, and a noſe like a bald-eagle!—ſee! ſee how he knits his brows!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Augh by my ſowl, and he ſhan't brow bate, me!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: He has truly a Coloſſean ſtature! a terrific appearance, and a belligerous phiz! but I'll manage him for all that! (The ghoſt continues to ſpit fire; with fire-balls and a roaring below. All kneel down.)

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: O! what an old ſinner I have been—I've brought myſelf into a ſad ſcrape! Mea culpa—

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Pray in Engliſh! pray in Engliſh! deſe pirate ſpirits don't underſtand de latin. (He lifts up his hands, and ſays) O! O! I don't know what to ſay.—O! O! I wiſh I hab lib'd a better life; do Mr. Waſhball ſay your prayers!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Dirrige, nos domine! I can't pray in Engliſh, do you ſay ſomething good to it. Oh! Mr. Rattletrap, I'm dead! I'm dead. Oh! Oh! (The fire-balls and roaring continues.)

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: Lord! have mercy upon us, and keep this devil from us! O! how my heart goes pit-a-pat? enough to break the Perricardum!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Cruciblarum, Advanſum! Perrilorum! (The ghoſt diſappears; they riſe.) He's almoſt conquer'd now! (The ghoſt appears again; ſpits fire with fire-balls; a terrible roaring below, they tremble and fall on their knees again.)

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p:
Right worſhipful maſter, no—As it was in de beginning—no, no, what is your name? Raccoon, who gib you dat name? my grand-moder and god-fader, no dats wrong—Our fader—I can't ſay it! Oh! Oh!
Oh! for eber and eber, Amen. Dare he comes, dare he comes again!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p:
(To Raccoon.) Lave off you black-mout! you havn't it, (he ſays) Pater-noſter, mea culpa, Sinner •
rum, helpum, deliverum, miſſerabulum, tuſcarorum.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: By me ſaul mon! 'tis the deel himſel! Ize ſee his claven foot!— (Aſide.) Troth and he makes me quack too, a wee-pickle!

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: Save us! Save us! from his fiery jaws! he's ſeeking whom he may devour.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Augh! and if he ſwallows me, by my ſowl! and I'll kick his guts out in the twinkling of a broomſtick!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! ſave me!—ſave me too!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: (To the ghoſt) Superiorum, lakeavi, hurorum! (The ghoſt diſappears) now's the lucky minute, the Serpent's-neck, is round the Poleaſter! Raiſe the cheſt, (They riſe, the ghoſt appears, and ſpits fire, with fire-balls, the roaring below increaſes, the diggers ſhrieking and trembling, thoſe without laugh at them.) Now, gentlemen, raiſe the cheſt, baniſh fear! keep faſt! (he calls to thoſe without) your aſſiſtance gentlemen or we loſe all! ſhould it ſink now, it's irrecoverably loſt! not all the magicians of Egypt, nor the witch of Endor cou'dn't recover it! quick gentlemen! quick! nows the intereſting moment!
sp.l: "There is a tide in the affairs of men,
"Which if taken at the flood, leads on to fortune."
sp.p: up with it.
sp.stage: (They run and aſſiſt in raiſing the cheſt.)

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: (Looking towards the ghoſt.) Dats Old Blackbeard himſelf! by de birtue and de power of de free and de accepted maſon, to me gibben, (here he gives the free-maſon's ſign, or ſomething like it) I command you to depaa • ! Oh! Oh! Oh what diſturbs dy poor ſoul from reſt?

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Horrificatabus, Profundum, Horridumque, Spectaculum, Demonium.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Haud fauſt, dinna quut yere grup, (he ſteps towards the ghoſt) noo I'ze ken him, I'ze gang after him.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Pray don't Mr. Buckram, it be de pirate apparition, did'n't you ſee how bery angry he look at me, when I did ſpeak to him?

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: The devil be from me, and I believe its Doctor Foſter!

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: The deel ma care, wha he be, Doctor Fauſtus, ſpirit, apparition, B • ackbeard, or the deel himſel, gin he con ſtond a cut o me Andra, he mun be the deel in troth. (He takes up his broad ſword, runs towards the ghoſt, makes a cut at it, and falls down; the ghoſt diſappears for a ſhort time; • eturns again ſpitting fire, the roaring continues more violent. Buckram lies on the ground, and ſays) Deil tak a warlocks I ſay, I ha leek to ha brok my neeke down the brae!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: By my ſowl! and you'd like to make a Somerſault of i • ! fath! and Ricketts is a nincompoop to you honey!

sp.speaker: Rat
sp.p: (Aſide) Ha! ha! ha! a comical dog.—That was a very impetuous, temerarius ſtep! didn't you know he's invulnerable? if I hadn't been here, you would have been incinerated, for your preſumption. (He ſteps up to the ghoſt, and ſays) Horridum, Callefridum, Buſcantivo, Interdenabulum! thus far will I permit thee to come, • ut no farther. Avaunt! Avaunt! Avaunt! and be thou laid in Lake Huron! 'till the waters thereof be exhauſted! (The ghoſt diſappears, with a dreadful noiſe) now we're all ſafe! Conſummatum et Triumphicatibus! up with the cheſt! thoſe fiends of darkneſs will trouble us no more.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p:
(Riſes up and ſhakes himſelf.) The deel a ſeeght mare, ye'ell ha o him noo he's gatten a ſmell o me
Andra! (they hoiſt up the cheſt, ſome black ruſty pieces of ſilver tumble out.)

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Now our toils are over, and we have caught our prey.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Huzza! huzza! huzza! &c.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: (Greedily taking up one of the pieces of ſilver, kiſſes it and ſays) Oh! my dear! my dear! (he rubs it and takes it to the lanthorn.) Let me ſee— (puts on his ſpectacles) One Thouſand, Sixteen Hundred and Eighty Four, aye! aye! this is the very money, that Blackbeard got at Panama, when he robb'd the churches! Oh! the poor prieſts! the poor prieſts! It ſeems very providentially to have fallen into my hands! Come! come! let's take it away, before day-light appears.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: May we preſume to take it away, Mr. Rattletrap?

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Jubileetatebuſque!—Finis cum fiſtulum, populorum jigg!—my buſineſs is finiſhed, therefore all's our own! away with it!

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: There's one thing proper firſt to mention, gentlemen, my ſiſter from whom I received the information, and to whom we are all ſo much indebted for this lucky turn of good fortune, is entitled to a ſhare; beſides, I think ſhe highly merits a handſome gratuitous preſent, as an acknowledgment of our gratitude to her.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: No, brudder Hum, I tink ſhe's titled to no more den half de ſhare, ſhe's no more den de woman. But, what do you mean by de preſent?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: A whole ſhare! I inſiſt upon it, is her juſt due! but, as for the preſent, that muſt be left to your generoſity, and I dare anſwer you'll not be wanting in munificence! what think you of one of the boxes of diamonds, or ſome ſuch trifle?

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: By all means!

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: Little enough in all conſcience!

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: I think ſo indeed! I would add one of the boxes of pearls to it!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Lord! Lord! no, no; I proteſt againſt a ſhare and a preſent too! we ſhall be ruin'd! ruin'd! Mr. Raccoon: indeed we ſhall, ſpeak to 'em, do ſir, do!

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Damme mon! but I thin the laſſie deſerves em a, an mare too!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Conſider! gentlemen, we hab run de riſk of our libes wid deſe ſpirits! beſides, what will de woman do wid ſo much of de dimonts, and de oder tings?

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Aye, indeed! I ſay the diamonds truly! why they are of more value than all the reſt of the things together! why you are all going mad!—mad!—mad! —indeed you are!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Fath an! ſhe ſhall have um all for me! and more too! by my ſowl! but I believe and you want 'um all yourſelf to hang up at your ſhop-winder, to make paple think how you're a toot-drawer, and don't you now, honey?

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I'm ſurprized! nay, almoſt petrified, at this ſudden change of ſentiments you have now expreſſed! you, who before you were poſſeſſed of this immenſe▪ treaſure, entertained ſuch lofty and laudable ideas of ambition, philanthropy and generoſity! you, who were for purchaſing titles, building and endowing hoſpitals and the Lord knows what! I ſay, gentlemen, I am aſtoniſh'd beyond meaſure at the change. Can it be poſſible! that you, who are now in actual poſſeſſion of this treaſure, you ſo ardently wiſhed for; and I ſay, gentlemen, on the attainment of which your pious reſolutions were ſounded, ſhould ſo ſuddenly change and turn traitors to that heaven-born
virtue, gratitude! and that Satan, that malignant, malicious, malevolent, miſchievous, unpropitious, peſtilential, peſtiferious, envious, ſpiteful, ungrateful devil! could ſo ſuddenly tranſform you into ſuch Judaſes, as even that moſt avaricious of all devils! Mammon himſelf! would bluſh at, hang down his head, and be aſhamed of. I muſt not! I cannot believe it!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Mighty fine talk indeed! but its nothing but wind!

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: Come, come! let's give the poor woman a full ſhare, and the diamonds and all; if it hadn't been for her we ſhou'dn't have had a copper!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: No, no! I forbid it!—I proteſt againſt it!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: (Aſide) Hoot you owld brute.

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: Let's put it to a vote?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: That's right! and ſhould that fail I proteſt! I'll give my whole ſhare to my ſiſter, and phillippic them to petrifaction!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: (Aſide, To Waſhball.) Who de debil's dis Philip Pick?

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: (Aſide) I ſuppoſe ſome ruffian of a fellow! he's going to ſet upon us to way-lay, rob and murder us!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Yes, I tink ſo too! Dad I'll always carry my piſtols in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: Vote! vote! (They vote and carry it for a full ſhare, and a preſent of a box of diamonds and a box of pearls.)

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Fath an I'm glad of it!

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I'm ſatisfy'd! and I heartily thank you in my ſiſter's name.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I tink its a bery great ſhame!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Oh, dear!—we're ruin'd!—we're ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: The day approaches; remove it immediately!

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: Where ſhall we carry it?

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: There's a cunning place in my houſe, I'll take care of it! it will be ſafe! I'll ſleep on it all night!

sp.speaker: All ſay.
sp.p: Agreed!—agreed!

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Now gentlemen, let's all meet preciſely at ſix o'clock this morning and divide it. I think ſome of us ſhou'd aſſiſt Mr. Waſhball; as this cheſt contains an immenſe treaſure, we can't be too careful; he's aged, and ſome unlucky circumſtance may intervene.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: No, no, I can take care of it, well enough.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Dat's right, brudder Hum, I tink I'd better go too, as I underſtand de military. If we ſhould be attack, my ſervice may be neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: Very true! and if Mr. Trowell, Mr. Truſhoop, and Mr. Buckram will attend you, it will be the ſafer.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: The devil burn Truſhoop, if he forſakes it!

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Deel tak the mon, that lags beheend!

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Well gentlemen! I think this great ſucceſs, deſerves a ſong; come bear chorus!

sp.speaker: All ſay.
sp.p: With all my heart.

lg.l: Tho' my art ſome deſpiſe, I appeal to your eyes,
For a proof of my magical knowledge,
Tho' the wiſdom of ſchools, damn our art and our tools,
We can laugh at the fools of the college.
Chorus. We can, &c.
Now my friends we're poſſeſt, of the glorious cheſt,
Join hands and rejoice beyond meaſure,
Let it be our firſt care, that great bleſſing to ſhare;
Whoſe contents, are an infinite treaſure!
Chorus. Whoſe, &c.

sp.p: Now gentlemen bear off your prize!

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Tak hauld Trowell, I'ze hurt me ſhouther in the fa' i' gat down the brae. I canna carry't lad! (The dupes take up the cheſt, and bear it off guarded by the humoriſts.)

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: It feels brave and ponderous.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: That's true for you!—fath! I woud'nt care if I break my back wid it. Arra deer! tread of my heels.

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: I beg your pardon!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Fath▪ an your very welcome—for the devil burn me, if I care for my heels at all, at all,—ſo I don't!— (Exeunt omnes, Buckram brings up the rear, flouriſhing his broad ſword, capering and ſinging a Scotch air.)

div.head: SCENE, II. A room in Waſhball's houſe.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Bleſs me! How could you venture (after the ſevere reproof my uncle gave you,) to approach this houſe, at this late hour of the night?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Love! angelic love! which knows no fear but your diſpleaſure, hath brought me here on eagle's wings, to waft you hence, and ſeal that vow, already ratified in heaven!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But conſider my dear Meanwell, what may be the conſequence of ſuch a raſh ſtep, when, perhaps a few days perſeverance, may bring it to a concluſion, with his conſent.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I cannot think of truſting to any thing ſo precarious, and as he has already conſented, by being my bondſman for the licence, and publicly declared his aſſent, we ſhall be looked upon by the honeſt, virtuous, and judicious, as ſufficiently juſtified in taking this ſtep.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I am confounded! my love to you ſpurs me to a ſlight! but my duty to my uncle, commands me to wait his reconciliation. I know not what to do, or, what to ſay!

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Haſte! haſte my dear Lucy! the precious moments are ſwiftly paſſing! each moment ſeems an hour 'till we're one, the clergyman waits, (with choſen friends) to tie the nuptial knot, and crown our bliſs!

lg.l: My throbbing heart muſt now give way
To love, to honor, and obey.
Lo! Hymen's torch is lighted.
Lo! Hymen's, &c.
My heart! my all!—I now reſign,
O! Meanwell!—Meanwell!—I'll be thine,
In wedlock's bands united!
In wedlocks, &c.
Of Venus' charms, let poets write!
Diana chaſte, or, Juno bright!
Of Kitty, Doll, or, Suſey!
Of Kitty, &c.
The charms of all, are center'd here,
In Lucy!—charming Lucy dear!
Haſte! haſte! my lovely Lucy!
Haſte, &c.

div.stage: They go off quick, hand in hand.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p:
I can't bear the thoughts of dividing, not I! diviſion! why I cou'd never learn it at ſchool! but, addition and multiplication, were always my darlings! Two hundred and fifty thouſand pounds, divided into nine parts, let me ſee—aye! I have it! nine times nine is, a, a, ſixty-two, no, that's wrong. Nine times eleven is, a, a hundred and ſix, and four over, no that's too much, but I'm no ſcholar, never mind, no matter,
I can count a hundred as faſt as any of 'em, and they can't cheat me! Charity begins at home, and he muſt be the greateſt fool on earth, that cheats himſelf; I never could forgive my ſelf for ſuch a ſin as that, I think I am old enough to have more wit. He that cheats another, can wipe off the ſin, by reſtoring four-fold, but he that cheats himſelf; poor ſoul! the ſin will lie at his own door, and it will never be in his power to make himſelf reſtitution! no, no, I know better; that muſt be the crying, that is ſpoken of by Lazarus, Nicodemus, Judas, or ſome other prophet, I forget who now; alack! its many years ago, ſince I read the bible, no matter. I'll e'en go and inform the Collector, then I ſhall have one half to myſelf, and the other will go the Preſident of the United States. They'll call me traitor and informer, but I don't care, let them laugh that wins, ha! ha! It's an old ſaying and a true one, aye, I have it! "One bird in hand is better far, than two that's in the buſh,"—no, no, "than two that in buſhes are." Aye, that's it! I remember it's ſo on my neighbour Simmond's ſign, I love to make rhimes, when they jingle ſo cleverly, but here's two hundred and fifty thouſand birds in the cage, and moſt of them pretty yellow birds! Oh! they'll make delightful muſic, and make me ſing too! I mus'n't loſe any time, no, ind • ed! (He looks up) I think this is the houſe, aye! (knocks at the door ſeveral times, and call ▪) Mr. Collector! Mr Collector! (Collector appears at the window, in his ſhirt and night-cap.)

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Who's there! and what's your urgent buſineſs, diſturbing my reſt ſo ſoon in the morning?

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Why, why ſir, its buſineſs of very great importance!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Importance, or not, I think you might have ſtay'd 'till day light.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: I coud'n't ſir—indeed I coud'n't!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I'm not us'd to have my reſt broke, at this unſeaſonable hour!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Sir, ſir!—we'll ſatisfy you handſom'ly for this extraordinary inconvenience!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (Aſide.) That's ſpeaking to the point!—Oh! very well!—very well!—what is the buſineſs, ſir?

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Why, why, ſir! I have an information, to lay before you, concerning a cheſt of treaſure—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A cheſt of treaſure? ſir.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Yes! ſir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A cheſt of treaſure? I don't underſtand you, ſir!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: (Aſide) The deuce you dont? the fellow's ſtupid.—I ſay, a cheſt of treaſure.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Explain yourſelf, ſir!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: 'Tis already explain'd!—I tell you, ſir! it's a cheſt of treaſure that we dug out of the ground laſt night.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Laſt night!—where?

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Why, why, ſomewhere—but I hav'n't time to tell you now. Come down! ſir—pray come!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What! a large cheſt?

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: (Aſide) What a fool he is. Yes! a large cheſt and very heav • : I know I help'd to carry it, and it almoſt kill'd me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, how long is it?

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Why, why! ſix foot long; as long as a coffin, (aſide) and when it's emptied, I wiſh you were buried in it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Can you be ſerious, ſir?

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p:
(Aſide.) This fellow will exhauſt all my patience. Yes, yes! I am, I am! myſelf and ſeveral others are concerned in it, and it grieves my conſcience to cheat the Preſident out of his lawful right; ſo, pray ſir, ſeize it, ſeize it, inſtantly, for me and
the Preſident. I expect all concerned will be at my houſe directly to open and ſhare it. Come, make haſte ſir, do!—Put the broad P on it, and then we ſhall be ſafe: you muſt act for me and the Preſident, and we'll reward you handſomely.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I'm afraid you're too ſanguine, and it's all deception!

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: (Aſide) What a curſed fool he is!—No! no! it an't, it an't; it's a real fact! here's occular demonſtration! for this piece of money, (ſhewing the piece) dropt out of the cheſt when we took it out of the ground. Look here, ſir! ſee it! ſee it!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Say you ſo?

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: True, ſir, true! pray be expeditious, do ſir, do, I inſiſt upon it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well ſir!—ſince you inſiſt upon it, I mu •• ſeize it.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: I do! I do! my fidelity to the United States, obliges me to inſiſt upon it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Remember your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: We'll ſatisfy you, nobly.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I ſhall look to you alone, ſir.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Very well! very well! I'll be your paymaſter. (Aſide) Since you're afraid to truſt my part'ner. Come down, ſir! do, do.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I'll wait on you inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: He's curſedly afraid of truſting my part'ner. Ha! ha! ha! I ſhall ſoon let him know what a ſervant he has; a dilatory, ſuſpicious dog! I'll have him turned out, as ſure as he was put in. (Collector enters the ſtreet.) This way, ſir! this way. Follow me, ſir! quick! quick! or we ſhall be too late.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Lead on, ſir! lead on. (Exeunt.)

div.head: SCENE IV. A Room in WASHBALL's Houſe.
div.stage:
(Scene opens and diſcovers TRUSHOOP, RACCOON, TROWELL, and BUCKRAM,
• itting on a cheſt, and OLD GABRIEL ſtanding by.)

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: Gabriel, where's your maſter?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Juſt ſtepp'd out.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Will he be in ſoon?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Ave—may be ſo.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: Oh!—here he comes, but who the devil's that with him?

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: The collector! egad! This is what I didn't expect. (Aſide.) It will not do to dupe him, we muſt let him into the ſecret.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: (Takes the collector aſide and ſays) Sir, I am ſorry you have been put to this trouble; it's a ſcheme of diverſion only; pleaſe not to notice it; I'll acquaint you with the whole hiſtory of it when it is concluded.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (Aſide) Ha! ha! Juſt as I thought knowing your funny character.—Mr. Hum, your ſervant—gentlemen yours. (Going.)

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Sir! ſir! ſtay, pray do your duty!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sir,—its an affair too intricate for me at preſent, I muſt firſt adviſe with the States Attorney General.

sp.speaker: Waſh
sp.p: You ſhan't go!—I inſiſt upon it, I charge you in the Preſident's name, ſeize it! ſeize it!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I muſt firſt have advice, then I'll return again.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: I forbid you to go at your peril! I'll inform the Preſident, and you ſhall be hang'd for not doing your duty.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
I can't help that!
(Ex • t.) — (Waſhball attempts to go after him, they ſtop him and he bawls.) Let me alone! let me alone!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Augh!—you curſed owld traytor, arn't you aſham'd now, to be chating us after this way?

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: I never heard of ſuch another villain.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: O Lord,—oh!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: (Aſide) There's queer doings here.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Ye • enfemous auld ſkoo • dre • ! ye turn'd eenformer, and ſtates-evedence, to get the ane • alf till yere ſel, but yere oot noo, troth and I'ze a mine to leeghten yere heed by ane o yere luggs.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: (Aſide) Worſe and worſe.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: O Lord,—oh!

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: What did you tink, we are all fools to be cheated by you?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Nothing can equal this! open the cheſt, who knows but the States-attorney may be on our backs immediately?

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Had I ſuſpected this before, I could have ſummon'd a whole hoſt of infernals, to have carried him away in a whirl-wind.

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: 'Tis a pity • ut you had, indeed.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Arra my deer! and give me a little bit of an •• der, and I'll fatch 'um in a jiffin.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: I ſhall have no more power, Mr. Truſhoop, 'till the moon changes.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Fath, an I'm ſorry for that honey.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: O Lord,—oh!

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: A traitor and an informer, gentlemen, of all mankind, are the moſt deſpicable of all wretches; you ſee gentlemen, the turpitude of that old curmudgeon's heart; after his moſt ſolemn oath of ſecrecy and honeſty, he thinks nothing of betraying his beſt friends, (Judas like) and his own ſoul, for the ſake of his body! without the leaſt regard for a ſacred and ſolemn oath!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: (Aſide) How he abuſes my maſter.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: Mr. Truſhoop where's your adz? open the cheſt.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Augh my deer, and here we are, bote at your ſharviſs.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: (Strives to prevent him, and call.) Mr. Collector! M • . Collector!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Stand off, you old ſlubberdegullion, (opening the cheſt, Hum, Parchment, Quadrant, and Rattletrap, holding Waſhball, he ſtruggles to get from them, and bawls out) where's the Collector? where's the Collector? touch it at your perils, you villains! I'll ſwear robbery againſt you! help Gabriel, help!

sp.speaker: Gab
sp.p: (Aſide) Lack-a-day, I believe they're going to rob my maſte • ! I would help him with all my heart, but my ſcuffling days are all over long ago.

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: Go on with your buſineſs gentlemen,—open the cheſt.— (Truſhoop, Trowell, Raccoon, and Buckram open the cheſt.)

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Touch it at your peril, I ſay. It belongs to me and my partner.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Belongs to the devil, you ti • f—we'll ſoon ſee who'll fa • e the ſharing it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: (Aſide) I never ſee the like before.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Help—help!—murder—murder—fire—thieves —Betty, Betty, bring down the bags you made —Run Gabriel for the Collector! Oh, oh, I'm juſt dead.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes, I wi • l, and the Conſtable too. Sorrow on me, but I believe they'll murder my maſter.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Dare! de cheſt opens. (They let Waſhball go, he runs towards the cheſt, the dupes all ſtriving to get their ſhares.)

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Give me my ſhare!—give me my ſhare.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: The devil a copper you tief.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p:
The deel a bawbie, ye ſhall ha' mon.—
(In the ſcuff •• they overſet the cheſt, puſh down Waſhball, and out tumble
the contents, the dupes looking at each other confuſed.)

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Hoo • mon—wha the deel's a this?—naething but ſtanes!—I ken we'll enaugh, wha it is—deil damme, but I'ze ha'gentelman's ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: De tivel—dis de ſcheme of brudder Hum. I ſecond your reſolution, do you gib de chalenge Mr. Buckram.

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: Oh mercy!— (Exit Hum, Parchment, Quadrant, and Rattletrap.)

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Augh hough!—fath, and we're all humbugged.

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: Its all a cheat.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Augh! but this will be my heart breaking—by my ſowl! and I've been made a fool for the future,— but I'll take care for the time to cum.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I didn't tink br • dder Hum wou'd ſerve me ſo, but dad I'll inform de Lodge of dis—dare's Rattletrap too wid his ſtars and tings,—plague on dem all— and hab Mrs. Placket made de fool of me too, wid her conjur-book? I tink it can't be ſo nader, for ſhe lobes me, or ſhe wou'dn't call me her Cooney—cock-a-pigeon—cock-a-dandy, and all de fine tings, dad I'll—

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Oh! I'm cheated—I'am abus'd, and made a fool of—I ſhall die, Oh! dear I ſhall die! (lifting up his hands) "poor Waſhball, diſappointed Waſhball."

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: (Looking ſurpris'd with his hands clench'd, aſide.) What's all this! alack-a-day. (Hum, Parchment, Quadrant, and Rattletrap, peeping alternately, call Canoe!— Waſhball chaſing them, and endeavoring to ſtrike them with his • ane,) "get out of my houſe you villains," (Canoe!) "you dogs," (Canoe!) "you hell-hounds," (Canoe!) "O dear! O dear, I ſhall faint," (Canoe!) I'm dead! I'm dead," (he ſits down) "Oh, Oh, Oh, (Canoe!) they laugh, and run off.

sp.speaker: Trow.
sp.p: A miſerable diſappointment.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
